awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Low Cost Metal Chelate Flow Battery for Long Duration Energy Storage
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project develops the chemistry for a new flow battery used to store energy for the electric grid. The battery chemistry uses abundant minerals and materials that can be sourced and manufactured in the United States. These flow battery materials support long duration energy storage of 4 to 100 hours – enough to back up the grid and support increased use of intermittent power sources such as solar and wind. This flow battery technology aims to meet aggressive cost targets for grid-scale storage, positioning the company to take advantage of the domestic and international market demand for energy storage. The battery system provides an opportunity for the U.S. to own high impact battery technology and claim a leadership position in the long duration energy storage market. 

This SBIR Phase I project seeks to lower the materials costs of a metal chelate flow battery for 10+ hour storage durations with greater than 80% round-trip efficiency. The goal is to develop a material purification process that uses low-grade minerals and removes key impurities with minimal waste. This goal will be achieved through the development and construction of a chemical purification system that selectively removes the impurities present in the low-grade minerals. The process will be validated by the demonstration of a flow battery operating with 10+ hours of continuous discharge at full power. The research and development effort focuses on a holistic solution to flow battery performance via a new chemistry that optimizes cost, abundance, safety, and performance in a single platform for long duration energy storage. Areas of development include electrolyte purity, sensitivity to precursors, processes development, system fouling and electrolyte purity sensitivity, purification system design and recycling, and 10-24 hour discharge battery performance demonstration incorporating the new purification process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Otoro Energy’s NSF SBIR Phase I project focused on developing a purification process for Otoro’s metal-chelate flow battery.  A flow battery is a rechargeable battery consisting of two liquids that are charged and discharged. The liquids are simultaneously pumped through an electrochemical cell, where the battery is charged or discharged. Otoro’s metal-chelate electrolyte consists of a metal center surrounded by an organic chelate that attaches strongly to the metal center.

Otoro’s flow battery technology will provide flexible grid scale energy storage to utilities for 10-100 hours. Electric utilities are increasingly adding renewable energy generation to the grid to meet carbon neutrality goals, but this increasing renewable generation results in an unstable grid with increasing numbers of blackouts. Otoro’s flow battery is the solution to an unstable grid, bridging gaps between periods of renewable energy generation. Flow batteries can provide backup power during outages, which will help avoid negative public health events (such as lack of air conditioning during a summer power outage), avoid economic losses due to lack of power, and protect critical infrastructure (such as hospitals and emergency services).

Widely deploying Otoro’s flow battery also has multiple broader impacts beyond the stabilization of electricity grids discussed above. First, wide adoption of energy storage will result in a reduction of highly polluting power plants that are most often located in low-income communities. As more renewable energy is deployed, these fossil fuel plants will be shut down, improving the health of the people who live near the plants. Second, as a Colorado based company, Otoro is committed to providing American-made energy storage solutions and plans to form strong partnerships with other American suppliers and manufacturers to help strengthen the US economy.

Intellectual merit: Otoro successfully met the milestones of the NSF SBIR Phase I project. A variety of metal impurities were assessed to determine which were the most harmful to Otoro’s flow battery. Once the most harmful impurities were found, Otoro developed a purification process to remove these impurities from the flow battery liquid electrolytes. The resulting purified electrolytes produced a battery performance improvement of 63%. This purification process increased the efficiency of Otoro’s flow battery, which makes the resulting commercial product more competitive with other technologies.


Last Modified: 09/23/2024
Modified by: Jessica Murdzek
